Governor [[Jerry Brown]] issued an executive order in March 2012 that established the goal of getting 1.5 million [[California Air Resources Board#California zero-emissions vehicle|zero-emission vehicle]]s (ZEVs) in California by 2025.<ref name=ZEVgoalCal>{{cite web |url=http://gov.ca.gov/news.php?id=17463 |title=Governor Brown Announces $120 Million Settlement To Fund Electric Car Charging Stations Across California |author=Staff |publisher=Office of Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr. |date=2012-03-23 |accessdate=2014-09-22}}</ref><ref name=SFG092014>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Brown-signs-several-clean-air-vehicle-bills-5771184.php |title=Brown signs several clean-air vehicle bills |author=Marisa Lagos |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=2014-09-22 |accessdate=2014-09-22}}</ref> In January 2018, Governor Brown set a new goal of getting a total of 5 million zero-emission vehicles in California by 2030.<ref name=Cal5mi>{{cite news | url=https://www.presstelegram.com/2018/02/04/california-on-path-to-meet-goal-of-1-5-million-electric-cars-but-charging-stations-lag-behind/ |title=California on path to meet goal of 1.5 million electric cars, but charging stations lag behind | first=Steve |last=Scauzillo | work=Press-Telegram | date=2018-02-04| accessdate=2018-02-05}}</ref>
California is the largest American car market with about 10% of all new car sales in the country.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2013/03/cec-20130301.html |title=California Energy Commission awards $4.5M to ARB for more clean vehicle rebates |author=California Energy Commission |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2013-03-01 |accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref> {{As of|2018|10}}, cumulative sales of plug-in cars totaled 491,000 units, making California the leading plug-in market in the country.<ref name=Cal102018>{{cite web|url=https://insideevs.com/plug-in-electric-car-sales-500000-california/ |title=Plug-In Electric Car Sales To Surpass 500,000 This Month In California | first=Mark | last=Kane | publisher=InsideEVs.com |work=VELOZ | date=2018-11-09| accessdate=2018-11-09}}</ref> The state accounted for approximately 48% of cumulative plug-in sales in the American market from 2011 to June 2016, and also accounted for about 50% of nationwide all-electric car sales and 47% of total plug-in hybrid sales.<ref name=CARB2016>{{cite web |url=https://www.arb.ca.gov/msprog/acc/mtr/acc_mtr_summaryreport.pdf |title=California’s Advanced Clean Cars Midterm Review: Summary Report for the Technical Analysis of the Light Duty Vehicle Standards |author=[[California Air Resources Board]] (CARB) |publisher=CARB |date=2017-01-18 |accessdate=2017-01-19}} ''See pp. ES 44.''</ref> Plug-in electric cars represented about 0.5% of the passenger fleet on the Californian roads by September 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/science/la-me-adv-ozone-transportation-20151011-story.html |title=Cutting ozone will require radical transformation of California's trucking industry |author=Tony Barboza |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2015-10-11 |accessdate=2015-10-11}}</ref>
Until December 2014 California not only had more plug-in electric vehicles than any other American state but also more than any other country in the world.<ref name=Cal2014>{{cite news |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/californians-bought-more-plug-in-cars-than-china-last-year/ |title=Californians Bought More Plug-in Cars Than China Last Year |author=Jeff Cobb |work=HybridCars.com |date=2015-03-18 |accessdate=2015-03-18}}</ref><ref name=SJMN092014>{{cite news |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_26493736/california-charges-ahead-electric-vehicles |title=California charges ahead with electric vehicles |author=Dana Hull |work=[[San Jose Mercury News]] |date=2014-09-08 |accessdate=2015-03-15}}</ref> In 2015 only two countries, Norway (22.4%) and the Netherlands (9.7%), achieved a higher plug-in market share than California.<ref name=Calif2015>{{cite news |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/california-plug-in-sales-led-us-last-year-with-nearly-five-times-greater-market-share/ |title=California Plug-in Sales Led The US Last Year With Nearly Five-Times Greater Market Share |first=Jeff |last=Cobb |work=HybridCars.com |date=2016-02-17 |accessdate=2016-02-18}} ''California's plug-in electric car market share was 3.1%, ranking behind only two countries, the Netherlands (9.7%) and Norway (22.7%). The administrative territory of Hong Kong also had a higher market share of 4.8%.''</ref> By November 2016, with about 250,000 plug-in cars sold in the state since 2010, China was the only country market that exceeds California in terms of cumulative plug-in electric car sales.<ref name=Cal250K>{{cite news |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/california-celebrates-one-quarter-million-plug-in-cars-sold/ |title=California Celebrates One-Quarter Million Plug-in Cars Sold |first=Jeff |last=Cobb |work=HybridCars.com |date=2016-11-14 |accessdate=2016-11-15}}</ref> In 2015, California's plug-in car market share was 4.7 times higher than the U.S. market, and registrations of plug-in electric cars in the state in 2015 represented 54.5% of total plug-in car sales in the U.S. that year.<ref name=Calif2015/> California's plug-in car market share was 3.5% of new car sales in 2016, while the U.S. take-rate was 0.90%.<ref name=Sales2016US/><ref name=Calif4Q2016>{{cite web |url=http://www.cncda.org/CMS/Pubs/CA%20Auto%20Outlook%204Q%202016.pdf |title=State New Vehicle Market Up Slightly in 2016; Similar Outlook for 2017 |author=California New Car Dealers Association (CNCDA) |publisher=CNCDA |date=February 2017 |accessdate=2017-02-24 |volume=13 |number=1}} ''Registrations through December 2016 since 2012. Revised figures for 2015.''</ref> In 2017, the state's market share reached nearly 5%, while the national share was 1.1%.<ref name=Calif4Q2017/><ref name=Cal5mi/><ref name=Sales2017US/>
[[File:PEV sales US California 2010 2017.png|thumb|300px|Comparison of annual sales of plug-in electric vehicles in the United States versus California between 2010 and September 2018<ref name=Calif4Q2014>{{cite web |url=http://www.cncda.org/CMS/Pubs/Cal_Covering_4Q_14.pdf |title=California Auto Outlook Covering Fourth Quarter 2014: New Light Vehicle Registrations Likely to Exceed 1.9 million units in 2015 |author=California New Car Dealers Association (CNCDA) |publisher=CNCDA |date=February 2015 |accessdate=2015-03-15}} ''Registrations through December 2014 since 2010.''</ref><ref name=Calif4Q2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.cncda.org/CMS/Pubs/Cal%20Covering%204Q%2015.pdf |title=California New Vehicle Registrations Expected to Remain Above 2 Million Units in 2016 |author=California New Car Dealers Association (CNCDA) |publisher=CNCDA |date=February 2016 |accessdate=2016-02-17 |volume=12 |number=1}} ''Registrations through December 2015 since 2011. Revised figures for 2014.''</ref><ref name=HybridCars/><ref name=Calif4Q2017>{{cite web |url=http://cncda.org/CMS/Pubs/California%20Covering%204Q%202017.pdf |title=New Vehicle Registrations in State Predicted to Exceed 2 Million Units Again in 2018 |author=California New Car Dealers Association (CNCDA) |publisher=CNCDA |date=February 2018 |accessdate=2018-02-17 |volume=14 |number=1}} ''Registrations through December 2017 since 2013.''</ref><ref name=Calif3Q2018>{{cite web |url=https://www.cncda.org/wp-content/uploads/Cal-Alt-Powertrain-Report-3Q-18-Release.pdf |title=New Vehicle Registrations in State To Approach 2 million Unit Mark in 2018 |author=California New Car Dealers Association (CNCDA) |publisher=CNCDA |date=November 2018 |accessdate=2018-11-23 |volume=14 |number=4}} ''Registrations through September 2018 since 2014.''</ref>]]
======Incentives======
{{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=left|image1=Cal green sticker CMax Energi 04 2015 SFO 2530.JPG|caption1=California's green Clean Air Vehicle sticker for plug-in hybrids|image2=Cal white sticker Model S 04 2015 Berkeley 1845.JPG|caption2=California's white Clean Air Vehicle sticker for all-electric cars}}
California has been a leader in the promotion of plug-in electric vehicles as the state has in place several financial and non-financial incentives. In addition to the existing [[Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles#Federal government|federal tax credit]], PEVs are eligible for a purchase rebate of up to {{USD|2,500}} through the [[Clean Vehicle Rebate Project]] (CVRP).<ref name="CVRPFAQ1"/> Also, [[battery electric vehicles]] and initially, the first 40,000 applicants that purchase or lease a [[plug-in hybrid]] meeting California’s Enhanced Advanced Technology Partial Zero Emission Vehicle (Enhanced AT PZEV), are entitled to a clean air sticker that allows the vehicle to be operated by a single occupant in California's [[carpool]] or [[high-occupancy vehicle lane]]s (HOV). The white access sticker is reserved for zero-emissions vehicles, while plug-in hybrids use the green sticker.<ref name=CAVdecal>{{cite web |url=http://www.dmv.ca.gov/vr/decal.htm |title=Clean Air Vehicle (CAV) Decals - High Occupancy Vehicle HOV Lane Usage |author=[[California Department of Motor Vehicles]] |publisher=DMV California |date=March 2014 |accessdate=2014-03-23}}</ref> {{As of|2016|09}}, the limits for plug-in hybrids and experation dates have been extended several timeas, and both the white and green stickers have the same expiration date, January 1, 2019.<ref name=ARB_HOVlist>{{cite web |url=https://www.arb.ca.gov/msprog/carpool/carpool.htm |title=Eligible vehicle list: Single ocuupant carpool lane stickers |author=[[California Air Resources Board]] (CARB) |publisher=CARB |date=2016-09-19 |accessdate=2016-09-19}}</ref><ref name=NoCapHOV>{{cite news |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/california-removes-green-sticker-cap-for-unlimited-phev-solo-hov-lane-access/ |title=California Removes ‘Green Sticker’ Cap For Unlimited PHEV Solo-HOV Lane Access |first=Jeff |last=Cobb |work=HybridCars.com |date=2016-09-19 |accessdate=2016-09-19}}</ref>
In March 2016 California added income-based caps to its rebate system. Buyers with incomes less than 300% of the [[Federal poverty level]] will get up to {{USD|3,000}} for a plug-in hybrid, {{USD|4,000}} for an all-electric car, and {{USD|6,500}} for a hydrogen fuel-cell car and the rebate scales down until Californian buyers with incomes over {{USD|250,000}} are no longer are eligible for incentives on hybrids or electric cars, however can get {{USD|5,000 for a hydrogen fuel-cell car}}.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1098988_california-ends-electric-car-rebates-for-wealthiest-buyers-boosts-them-for-poorest |title=California Ends Electric-Car Rebates For Wealthiest Buyers, Boosts Them For Poorest |first=Stephen |last=Edelstein |work=Green Car Reports |date=2015-07-15 |accessdate=2015-07-28}}</ref> As of March 2016, the Center for Sustainable Energy has issued more than $291 million in the CVRP for over 137,200 vehicles since 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://electrek.co/2016/03/15/psa-california-clean-vehicle-rebate/ |title=PSA: California Clean Vehicle Rebate is increasing for low- and moderate-income drivers, and going away for high-income drivers on March 29 |first=Fred |last=Lambert |work=Electrek |location=US |date=2016-03-15 |access-date=2016-08-24}}</ref> The income-base caps went into effect on 1 November 2016. Residents will not be eligible for rebates if their gross annual income exceeds {{USD|150,000}} for single tax filers, {{USD|204,000}} for head of household filers and {{USD|300,000}} for joint filers. These limits do not apply to the purchase of [[fuel cell electric vehicle]]s, which represent less than 1% of rebate applications.<ref name=CVRP112016>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2016/11/20161108-berk.html |title=Berkeley study finds clean vehicle rebates have predominantly benefited wealthy, white Californians |first=Mike |last=Millikin |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2016-11-08 |accessdate=2016-11-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-electric-car-rebates-20161031-story.html |title=California's electric-car rebates jump for lower-income buyers and vanish for more high earners |first=Rob |last=Nikolewski |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2016-10-31 |accessdate=2016-11-09}}</ref>
=====Georgia===== [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] ranked second in the U.S. after California in terms of total plug-in electric vehicles on the road by mid-2014 .<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nj.com/business/index.ssf/2014/06/evironmentalists_say_nj_should_do_more_to_promote_electric_vehicles.html |title=Report urges NJ must do more to promote 'promise of electric vehicles' |author=Alexi Friedman |work=[[The Star-Ledger]] |date=2014-06-29 |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref> During the first half of 2014 Georgia ranked as the top selling all-electric car market in the U.S. at the state level with a 1.6% share of new light-vehicle registrations, ahead of California (1.41%), and up from 0.94% during 2013.<ref name=TopBEVsates2013_062014/> {{As of|2014|08}}, there were about 12,000 electric vehicles registered in the state, of which, about 80% are registered in [[Atlanta metropolitan area|metro Atlanta]]’s five core counties.<ref name=Atlanta12K>{{cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/print-edition/2014/08/08/atlanta-eyeing-incentives-to-install-vehicle.html?page=all |title=Atlanta eying incentives to install vehicle chargers |author1=Urvaksh Karkaria |author2=Dave Williams |lastauthoramp=yes |work=[[Atlanta Business Chronicle]] |date=2014-08-08 |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref> In the 12 months between April 2013 and March 2014, metro Atlanta was the second top selling all-electric car metropolitan market in the U.S., with a market share of 2.15% of total new light-vehicle sales in the state, 5.6 times the national average share of 0.38%.<ref name=TopAtlantaMetro/> [[Savannah metropolitan area|Savannah]] ranks second in the state after Atlanta, with a market share of 0.13% of total new light-vehicle sales.<ref name=TopBEVmetro/>
Between August 2013 and May 2014, Atlanta was the top U.S. metropolitan market for the [[Nissan Leaf]] for eight out of the ten months,<ref name=TopAtlantaMetro/> and until July 2013, Atlanta was the third largest Leaf market behind [[San Francisco Bay Area|San Francisco]] and [[Los Angeles metropolitan area|Los Angeles]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://insideevs.com/atlanta-becomes-1-market-for-nissan-leaf/ |title=Atlanta Becomes #1 Market for Nissan LEAF |author=Eric Loveday |publisher=InsideEVs.com |date=2013-09-04 |accessdate=2014-09-28}}</ref> Leaf sales are favored by Georgia's law, which caps sales of electric vehicles sold direct by a manufacturer to 150, setting a restrictive limit to [[Tesla Model S]] sales, and the law excluded plug-in hybrids for eligibility to the state's tax credit.<ref name=TopAtlantaMetro/>
======Tax credits====== The State of Georgia considers [[alternative fuel vehicle]]s (AFVs) those that run solely on alternative fuel and do not run on regular gasoline. AFVs includes vehicles that operate using battery electricity, propane, natural gas, and hydrogen fuel cell.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.georgiaair.org/airpermit/html/mobilearea/engines/Alternativefuels.htm |title=Low Emission "Alternative Fuel" Vehicle Tax Credits in Georgia |author=[[Georgia Department of Natural Resources]] |publisher=Environmental Protection Division, Air Protection Branch |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref> As incentives to accelerate all-electric vehicle adoption, in addition to the existing {{USD|7,500}} federal tax credit, Georgia offers an [[tax credit|income tax credit]] of 20% of the vehicle cost up to {{USD|5,000}} for the purchase or leasing of a zero emission vehicle (ZEV). Plug-in hybrids are not eligible for this incentive because sometimes they are powered by electricity from their on-board combustion engine. There is also a 10% tax credit up to {{USD|2,500}} for the purchase and installation of qualified electric vehicle charger. This tax credit applies only to non-retail business enterprises and chargers installed at homes do not qualify.<ref name=GeorgiaTax>{{cite web |url=http://www.georgiaair.org/airpermit/downloads/mobilearea/engines/Alternative%20Fuels/levzevfs.pdf |title=LEV/ZEV and Electric Vehicle Charger Tax Credit Fact Sheet |publisher=[[Georgia Department of Natural Resources]] |date=2004-04-14 |accessdate=2014-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021055852/http://www.georgiaair.org/airpermit/downloads/mobilearea/engines/Alternative%20Fuels/levzevfs.pdf |archivedate=2014-10-21 |df= }}</ref> [[File:Tesla Roadster Georgia AFV license plate zoom in.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Tesla Roadster (2008)|Tesla Roadster]] with Georgia's Alternative Fuel Vehicle (AFV) license plate, which allows access to [[high occupancy vehicle lanes]] (HOV) regardless of number of passengers]]
An income tax credit for the purchase of a new commercial [[Medium-duty truck|medium-duty]] or [[Heavy-duty truck|heavy-duty]] AFVs started on July 1, 2015. Medium-duty [[hybrid electric vehicle]]s also qualify. Eligible medium-duty AFVs with a [[gross vehicle weight rating]] (GVWR) between {{Convert|8,500|to|26,001|lb|abbr=on}} qualify for a credit of up to {{USD|12,000}}, while heavy-duty AFVs with a GVWR over {{Convert|26,001|lb|abbr=on}} qualify for a credit of up to {{USD|20,000}}. The credit is capped at {{USD|250,000}} per taxpayer. Qualified AFVs must be purchased before June 30, 2017, remain registered in Georgia for at least five years, and accumulate at least 75% of their annual mileage in Georgia. Up to {{USD|2.5 million}} in total credits will be available each fiscal year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.afdc.energy.gov/laws/all?state=GA |title=Georgia Laws and Incentives |author=[[Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy]] |publisher=Alternative Fuels Data Center |date=2014-06-04 |accessdate=2014-09-28}}</ref>
======Access to HOV lanes====== The definition of alternate fuel vehicle for the purposes of an AFV License Plate in Georgia is different from the one for tax credit purposes. The [[Official Code of Georgia Annotated]] defines an AFV as a vehicle that has been certified by the EPA in accordance with the [[Clean Air Act (United States)|Federal Clean Air Act]], therefore, both all-electric vehicles and plug-in hybrids are eligible for Georgia's AFV license plate.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.plugingeorgia.com/pdf/library/GA_AFV_Incentive_Guide.docx |title=Georgia’s Alternative Fuel Vehicle Incentives |author=Plug-in Georgia |publisher=PluginGeorgia.com |accessdate=2014-09-27}} ''Download the Word file "GA_AFV_Incentive_Guide.docx"''</ref> All vehicles displaying a GA alternative fuel license plate are allowed to use [[high occupancy vehicle lanes]] (HOV) regardless of number of passengers. Alternative fuel vehicles displaying the proper alternative fuel license plat may obtain a Peach Pass [[electronic toll collection|electronic tag]] that grants them toll-free access to all Peach Pass controlled [[high-occupancy toll lane]]s (HOT) lanes.<ref name=PlugIncentives>{{cite web |url=https://www.plugincentives.com/blog/list-us-electric-vehicle-and-evse-incentives-state |title=List of U.S. Electric Vehicle and EVSE Incentives by State |author=PlugIncentives.org |publisher=PlugIncentives.org |date=2014-09-04 |accessdate=2014-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402092257/https://www.plugincentives.com/blog/list-us-electric-vehicle-and-evse-incentives-state |archivedate=2015-04-02 |df= }}</ref>
======Time-of-use electricity rates====== [[Georgia Power]], the primary utility in Atlanta, offers a [[Time of use net metering|time-of-use]] electric vehicle plan designed for plug-in charging. {{As of|2014|09}}, the plan has about 1,500 customers statewide.<ref name=TOUratesGA>{{cite news |url=http://savannahnow.com/news/2014-09-25/getting-charge-electric-vehicles-savannah |title=Getting a charge from electric vehicles in Savannah |author=Mary Landers |work=[[Savannah Morning News]] |date=2014-09-26 |accessdate=2014-09-28}}</ref> For a monthly fee of {{USD|10}}, the utility lowers the overnight rate to 1.3 cents per [[Kilowatt hour]] (kWh) while raising the peak rate, from 2-7 p.m. from June through September, to 20.3 cents per kWh. There is also a shoulder rate of 6.2 cents per Kwh in between those times.<ref name=TOUratesGA/> The average U.S. rate is 11.88 cents per kWh.<ref name=TopAtlantaMetro/>
======Charging infrastructure====== {{As of|2014|04}}, Georgia had 238 [[charging station]]s with 548 public outlets available across the state.<ref name=ChargePoints/> Of these, about 120 public charging stations are located in metro Atlanta, with only about half of these located inside the city limits of Atlanta. Considering the rapid growth of electric cars in the city, there is a shortage of charging infrastructure relative to supply of electric vehicles.<ref name=Atlanta12K/>
The city of Atlanta is considering legislation to attend the needs of electric car owners and others who want to provide electric vehicle charging at their business, multifamily dwelling or private home. The measure aims to remove a major barrier to owning an electric vehicle by encouraging office and residential landlords to install electric vehicle chargers and reserved parking. Under the proposal, each electric vehicle charging station would be counted as one parking space, and the minimum parking requirement for developers and builders would be reduced by one space for each charging station provided, allowing up to a 10% reduction in minimum parking requirements. The city also wants to simplify the process required to obtain a permit to install electric vehicle chargers and make the spaces more identifiable.<ref name=Atlanta12K/>
=====Hawaii===== [[File:Electric Car Charging Station Honolulu.jpg|thumb|upright|A public electric car [[charging station]] in Kaka'ako, [[Honolulu]], [[Oahu]], Hawaii]]
[[Hawaii]] has a high potential for mass adoption of plug-in electric vehicles due to the limited driving range imposed by the island geographies, and its high fuel costs, with gasoline prices, {{as of|2013|09|lc=y}}, ranging between {{USD|4.25}} and {{USD|5.00}} a gallon.<ref name=HawaiiParadise/><ref name=EVHawaii/> The number of registered plug-in electric vehicles increased from 581 units in 2011, to 967 in 2012,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.civilbeat.com/2013/07/19544-friday-factoid-hybrid-and-electric-cars-in-hawaii/ |title=Friday Factoid: Hybrid and Electric Cars in Hawaii |author=Staff |publisher=The Civil Beat |date=2013-07-19 |accessdate=2014-09-24}} ''Click on graph for annual sales of PEVS.''</ref> and reached 1,551 units in June 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://insideevs.com/electric-vehicles-registrations-up-83-percent-in-hawaii/ |title=Electric Vehicles Registrations Up 83% Percent in Hawaii |author=Eric Loveday |publisher=InsideEVs.com |date=2013-07-31 |accessdate=2014-09-23}}</ref> {{As of|2014|08}}, a total of 2,821 plug-in highway legal plug-in electric cars have been registered in Hawaii.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://files.hawaii.gov/dbedt/economic/data_reports/energy-trends/Energy_Trend.pdf |title=Monthly Energy Trend Highlights August 2014 |author=Research & Economic Analysis Division, DBEDT |publisher=Hawaii State Department of Business, Economic Development & Tourism (DBEDT) |date=September 2014 |accessdate=2014-09-24}} ''See Registered Taxable Vehicles, pp. 2.''</ref>
In terms of EV adoption, Hawaii ranked in 2013 as the state with the third highest all-electric car [[market share]] with 1.21% of new car sales, and during the first half of 2014 ranked fourth with a 1.04% market share.<ref name=TopBEVsates2013_062014/> Accounting for sales of pure electric cars between April 2013 and March 2014, the [[Honolulu metropolitan area]] ranks as the fourth top selling BEV metro market in the United States, with 1.71% of new car sales.<ref name=TopBEVmetro/>
In January 2011 the state implemented a purchase rebate of up to {{USD|5,000}} available for both the purchase of a plug-in electric car purchase and a charging station, but limited to {{USD|4,500}} for the vehicle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hawaii.gov/dbedt/info/energy/evrebatesgrants/rebates |title=Hawaii's Electric Vehicle (EV) Rebate Program |accessdate=2010-08-16}}</ref> The rebate ended in May 2012 as high consumer demand depleted the fund. More than 450 rebates were issued totaling about {{USD|2 million}}. Several efforts to add more funds were unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite news |last=Yonan |first=Alan Jr. |date=2012-05-18 |title=State runs short of funds for EV rebate |newspaper=[[Honolulu Star-Advertiser]] |url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/businesspremium/20120518_State_runs_short_of_funds_for_EV_rebate.html |accessdate=2014-09-20}} {{subscription required}}</ref>
===== Maryland =====
[[File:Nissan Leaf HOV sticker WAS 2012 0766.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Nissan Leaf with Maryland's sticker to identify plug-in electric vehicles eligible to use HOV lanes with solo drivers]]
{{As of|2015|12}}, there were 2,282 all-electric cars registered in Maryland. Sales of the Nissan Leaf and Tesla Model S account for about 70% of the electrics registered in the state.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/business/bs-bz-electric-cars-20160418-story.html |title=Electric car excitement remains limited in Maryland |first=Colin |last=Campbell |work=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |date=2016-04-18 |accessdate=2016-04-19}}</ref> As part of the incentives to promote electric vehicle adoption, drivers of approved plug-in electric vehicles can use Maryland's high occupancy vehicle (HOV) lanes at all times, even if they are traveling solo. This incentive is in effect until September 30, 2017.<ref name=DMV/>
Plug-in electric vehicles purchased new and titled for the first time between July 1, 2014, and July 1, 2017, are eligible for a credit up to {{USD|3,000}}, calculated as {{USD|125}} per [[kWh]] of battery capacity. Buyers of PEVs may apply for a tax credit against the imposed excise tax. The credit is returned to the taxpayer in the form of a check from the state. The tax credit is limited to one vehicle per individual and 10 vehicles per business. A qualified vehicle must meet the following criteria:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.afdc.energy.gov/laws/8381 |title=Plug-In Electric Vehicle (PEV) Tax Credit |date=2014-06-04 |publisher=Alternative Fuels Data Center, U.S. DoE |accessdate=2016-04-19}}</ref>
* Has a gross vehicle weight rating of 8,500 pounds or less; * Can achieve a maximum speed of at least 55 miles per hour; * Is a two-, three-, or four-wheeled vehicle; * Is propelled to a significant extent by an electric motor that draws electricity from a battery with a capacity of at least four kilowatt-hours (kWh) in the case of a four-wheeled motor vehicle, or at least two and a half kWh in the case of a two- or three-wheeled motor vehicle; * Has not been modified from original manufacturer specifications; and * Is purchased after October 1, 2010.
The state also offers a {{USD|900}} rebate for buying and installation of wall connectorsfor individuals, {{USD|5,000}} for business, or state or local governments, and {{USD|7,000}} for retail service station dealers. Between July 1, 2014, and June 30, 2016, rebate amounts are equal to the previous amounts, up to 50% of the costs of acquiring and installing qualified chargers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.afdc.energy.gov/laws/11423 |title=Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment (EVSE) Rebate Program |date=2014-06-04 |publisher=Alternative Fuels Data Center, U.S. DoE |accessdate=2016-04-19}}</ref>
=====New York===== The stock of plug-in electric vehicles in [[New York (state)|New York]] climbed from 1,000 units in early 2012, to over 10,000 plug-in vehicles by mid-September 2,014. The state of New York set the goal to deploy up to 3,000 EV charging stations in public and workplace locations across the state by 2018. {{As of|2014|09}}, there are about 1,000 charging stations.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.nypa.gov/Press/2014/091914.html |title=New Electric Vehicle Charging Stations Installed at Niagara Falls International Airport to Mark National Drive Electric Week |publisher=[[New York Power Authority]] |location=Niagara Falls |date=2014-09-14 |accessdate=2014-10-25}}</ref>
Plug-in electric vehicles and [[hybrid electric vehicle]]s with a combined fuel economy rating of at least {{Convert|45|mpgUS|abbr=on}} and that also meet the [[California Air Resources Board]] [[Super ultra-low emission vehicle|SULEV]] emissions standard, are eligible for the Clean Pass Program. Eligible vehicles which display the Clean Pass vehicle sticker are allowed to use the [[Long Island Expressway]] HOV lanes, regardless of the number of occupants.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dot.ny.gov/portal/page/portal/programs/clean-pass?nd=nysdot |title=New York's Clean Pass Program |author=[[New York State Department of Transportation]] (NYSDOT) |publisher=NYSDOT |date=2014-07-28 |accessdate=2014-10-25}}</ref> Drivers of qualified vehicles may also receive a 10% discount on established [[E-ZPass]] accounts with proof of registration.<ref name="Alternative Fuels Data Center AFDC"/> In New York state there are no purchase incentives.
=====Oregon=====
{{As of|2013|11}}, there were about 3,500 plug-in electric vehicles registered in [[Oregon]].<ref name=MNN2013>{{cite web |url=http://www.mnn.com/green-tech/transportation/blogs/why-some-states-are-selling-more-electric-cars-than-others |title=Why some states are selling more electric cars than others |author=[[Jim Motavalli]] |publisher=[[Mother Nature Network]] |date=2013-11-18 |accessdate=2014-09-28}}</ref> In 2013 the state was the fifth top selling all-electric car market in the U.S. at the state level with a 0.89% [[market share]] of new light-vehicle registrations, more than twice the national average share of 0.32%. During the first half of 2014 Oregon BEV share fell to 0.67% but continued to rank in the fifth place among the top selling states.<ref name=TopBEVsates2013_062014/>
In the 12 months between April 2013 and March 2014, two metropolitan areas in Oregon ranked among the top ten selling all-electric car metropolitan markets in the U.S. [[Portland metropolitan area|Portland]] ranked eighth with a 1.25% market share of total new light-vehicle sales, ahead of [[Los Angeles metropolitan area]], and [[Eugene metropolitan area|Eugene]] ranked in number 10 with a market share of 0.86%. The national average share during this period was 0.38%.<ref name=TopBEVmetro/>
======Incentives======
A {{USD|1,500}} tax credit for the purchase of a new all-electric vehicle is no longer available.<ref name=MNN2013/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.plugincars.com/federal-and-local-incentives-plug-hybrids-and-electric-cars.html |title=Federal and Local Incentives for Plug-in Hybrids and Electric Cars |author=Brad Berman |publisher=PluinCars.com |date=2014-08-25 |accessdate=2014-09-28}}</ref> There is a tax credit up to {{USD|750}} to cover 25% of the cost of purchasing and installing an electric vehicle charger station, and 35% for business owners. Beginning January 1, 2015, business owners that purchase two or more all-electric vehicles may be eligible for a tax credit of 35% of eligible costs for the incremental cost of purchasing the vehicles. This incentive ends on December 31, 2018.<ref name=PlugIncentives/>
======Electric Avenue====== [[File:Electric Avenue crooped.jpg|thumb|Electric Avenue charging stations at [[Portland State University]]]] Electric Avenue is a joint research and development initiative of [[Portland State University]] (PSU), [[Portland General Electric]] (PGE), and the [[Portland, Oregon|City of Portland]]. The Electric Avenue was launched in August 2011 to learn about the interaction and performance of charging stations and a variety of electric vehicles. The initiative also aimed to understand the charging preferences and travel patterns of electric vehicle visitors. The charging infrastructure includes quick chargers and both Level 1 and Level 2 charging stations powered by 100% [[renewable energy]] from PGE, and offers charging at standard city parking rates. The site comprises eight on street parking spaces with seven available charging stations located along an entire block. The Electric Avenue is located in the south end of downtown Portland, at the PSU’s campus adjacent to Portland’s [[Portland Transit Mall|Sixth Avenue Transit Mall]] where light rail trains, electric street cars, buses, cars, bikes, and pedestrians share a well-integrated personal and public transit corridor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pdx.edu/electricavenue/sites/www.pdx.edu.electricavenue/files/ElectricAveLessonsV1.pdf |title=Charging Forward: lessons learned from the first six months at Electric Avenue |author=Electric Avenue Initiative |publisher=[[Portland State University]] |date=June 2012 |accessdate=2014-09-28}}</ref>
=====Texas===== Texas is the second largest light-duty vehicle market in the U.S. after California, with over 20 million passenger and light truck vehicles registered at the end of 2013.<ref name=NADA2014>{{cite web |url=http://www.nada.org/NR/rdonlyres/DF6547D8-C037-4D2E-BD77-A730EBC830EB/0/NADA_Data_2014_05282014.pdf |title=NADA Data 2014: Annual Financial Profile of America's Franchised New-Car Dealerships |author=[[National Automobile Dealers Association]] (NADA) |publisher=NADA |year=2014 |accessdate=2014-09-27}}'' See table "Total light vehicles in operation in 2013, by state" pp. 16''.</ref> {{As of|2014|005}}, there were about 5,000 plug-in electric vehicles registered in the state.<ref name=TexasEVs>{{cite news |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1091959_texas-electric-car-purchase-rebates-up-to-2500-to-start-soon |title=Texas Electric-Car Purchase Rebates Up To $2,500 To Start Soon |author=Stephen Edelstein |work=Green Car Reports |date=2014-05-08 |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref> Accounting for sales of new all-electric vehicles between April 2013 and March 2014, the top three selling metropolitan markets in Texas in terms of market share of total new light-vehicle sales were the [[Austin metropolitan area]] with 0.47%, followed by [[Dallas-Ft. Worth]] with 0.21% and [[Greater Houston|Houston area]] with 0.15%.<ref name=TopBEVmetro/> The national average share for the period was 0.38%, with Austin ranking in 15th place, and together with [[metro Atlanta]], the only two cities in the top 15 that are not located on the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]].<ref name=TopAtlantaMetro>{{cite news |url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/why-electric-cars-click-for-atlanta-1401922534 |title=Atlanta's Incentives Lift Electric Car Sales |author=Mike Ramsey |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=2014-06-04 |accessdate=2014-09-28}} ''Sales of new all-electric vehicles in the 12 months that ended March 31, 2014. Source: IHS Automotive.''</ref>
In November 2013 the [[Texas Commission on Environmental Quality]] approved a rebate program to provide financial incentives up to {{USD|2,500}} for the purchase or lease of new eligible vehicles powered by [[compressed natural gas]] (CNG), [[liquefied petroleum gas]] (LPG), or plug-in electric drive with battery capacity larger than 4 [[kWh]].<ref name=TexasEVs/> The rebate amount for leasing depends on the lease term, only 4-year lease terms are eligible for the full {{USD|2,500}}, just like new car purchases.<ref name=LoneStar/> Total funding for the program is {{USD|7.7 million}}, and the maximum number of vehicles allowed is 2,000 units for each plug-in electric drive and natural gas/propane vehicles for the length of the program.<ref name=TexasEVs/><ref name=LoneStar>{{cite web |url=http://www.lonestarcfa.org/content/tceq-accepting-applications-light-duty-purchase-or-lease-incentive-program |title=TCEQ Accepting Applications for Light-Duty Purchase or Lease Incentive Program |publisher=Lone Star Clean Fuels Alliance |date=May 2014 |accessdate=2014-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140928001310/http://www.lonestarcfa.org/content/tceq-accepting-applications-light-duty-purchase-or-lease-incentive-program |archivedate=2014-09-28 |df= }}</ref> Only purchases made on or after May 13, 2014 are eligible to apply for a rebate, and the program ends June 26, 2015 or until funding ends. {{As of|2014|09|22}}, there were {{USD|6,7 million}} remaining in the rebate fund.<ref name=TCEQ>{{cite web |url=http://www.tceq.state.tx.us/airquality/terp/ld.html |title=Light-Duty Motor Vehicle Purchase or Lease Incentive Program |author=[[Texas Commission on Environmental Quality]] (TCEQ) |publisher=TCEQ |date=2014-09-23 |accessdate=2014-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140917010759/http://www.tceq.state.tx.us/airquality/terp/ld.html/ |archivedate=2014-09-17 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:Nissan LEAF got thirsty.jpg|thumb|left|[[Nissan Leaf]] charging in [[Houston]], Texas]]
Among plug-in cars sold nationwide, the [[Tesla Model S]] is not eligible for the rebate because only new PEVs purchased or leased from a dealer or leasing company licensed to operate in Texas may qualify. [[Tesla Motors]] is not authorized to sell its vehicles in the state due to its direct-sales business model.<ref name=TexasEVs/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1087815_tesla-underground-texas-franchise-rules-make-model-s-owners-skirt-the-law |title=Tesla Underground: Texas Franchise Rules Make Model S Owners Skirt The Law |author=David Noland |work=Green Car Reports |date=2013-10-22 |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tceq.state.tx.us/assets/public/implementation/air/terp/ld/2014_ld_list.pdf |title=Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) Light-Duty Motor Vehicle Purchase or Lease Incentive Program (LDPLI) - Eligible Vehicle List |author=[[Texas Commission on Environmental Quality]] (TCEQ) |publisher=TCEQ |date=2014-08-29 |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref> But customers can buy directly from the company's website like in any other state.
======Texas River Cities Plug-In Electric Vehicle Initiative======
Despite the low penetration of plug-in electric vehicles in the state, the Texas River Cities Plug-In Electric Vehicle Initiative (TRC) is one of the most comprehensive plans for electric vehicles and their infrastructure aimed to increase the long-term success of PEV adoption. The TRC initiative encompasses two major metropolitan areas in and around [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] and [[San Antonio]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.texasfuelindependence.org/pev/drivers/basics-101/trc-report/ |title=Texas River Cities Plug-In Electric Vehicle Initiative |author=Texas River Cities Plug-In Electric Vehicle Initiative |publisher=Central Texas Fuel Independence Project |date=2014-09-16 |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref> [[Austin Energy]], one of the project partners, had deployed 239 utility-operated publicly accessible charging stations in the TRC region by 2012. The utility company is the recipient of the [[U.S. Department of Energy]] funding for this initiative. The TRC region is projected to have 4,259 PEVs in 2015 and 17,336 in 2020.<ref name=TRCsummary>{{cite web |url=http://www.texasfuelindependence.org/assets/docs/TRC/TRC%20Executive%20Summary.pdf |title=Executive Summary of the Texas River Cities Plug-in Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Plan |author=Texas River Cities Plug-In Electric Vehicle Initiative (TRC) |publisher=Central Texas Fuel Independence Project |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref>
======Pecan Street demonstration project====== This demonstration project is run by the Pecan Street Inc., a [[University of Texas]] based research consortium of research and industry partners focused on developing and testing advanced technology, business model, and customer behavior surrounding energy management systems. The project is supported by a {{USD|10.4 million}} [[smart grid]] demonstration grant from the U.S. Department of Energy and more than {{USD|14 million}} in matching funds from the project partners. The demonstration project began in 2010 and is taken place with volunteer residents at the Mueller neighborhood, a planned green community in Austin. The Pecan Street hosts an electric vehicle research program and provides incentives to participants with rebates of {{USD|3,000}} and {{USD|7,500}} to lease or purchase a PEV that is in addition to the federal tax credits. Through the research program, Pecan Street is studying grid load and monitoring home energy use through management equipment. As a result of the incentive program, Mueller has more plug-in electric vehicles per capita than any other U.S. neighborhood.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pecanstreet.org/projects/smart-grid-demonstration/ |title=The Pecan Street Project |author=Pecan Street Inc. |publisher=PecanStreet.org |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://time.com/2926417/is-this-americas-smartest-city/ |title=Is This America’s Smartest City? |author=Bryan Walsh |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=2014-06-24 |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref><ref name=TRCreport>{{cite web |url=http://www.texasfuelindependence.org/assets/docs/TRC/TRC-EVI%20Report%202012-10-25%20FINAL.pdf |title=Texas River Cities Plug-in Electric Vehicle Initiative Regional Plan and Final Report |author=Texas River Cities Plug-In Electric Vehicle Initiative (TRC) |publisher=Central Texas Fuel Independence Project |accessdate=2014-09-27}} See pp. 3</ref>
[[General Motors]] is a sponsor of the Pecan Street demonstration and is supporting the project to learn the charging patterns of plug-in electric car owners, and to study how a residential fleet of electric vehicles might strain the electric grid if all owners try to charge them at the same, which is what the preliminary monitoring found when the plug-in cars return home in the evening. {{As of|2013|06}}, the community had nearly 60 [[Chevrolet]] Volt owners alone thanks to GM's commitment to match the federal government's {{USD|7,500}} rebate incentive, which halves the purchase price of the Volt.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=remote-control-of-electric-cars |title=Will You or the Grid Control Your Electric Car? |author=David Biello |work=[[Scientific America]] |date=2013-06-18 |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref>
=====Washington=====
The state set a goal to have 50,000 electric or other clean vehicles on the road by 2020.<ref name=Incentives/> {{As of|2016|06|30}}, there were 30,701 battery-powered and plug-in electric cars registered in [[Washington (state)|Washington]].<ref name="WSDOT2016">{{cite web |title=PEV Registration by County by Make |url=http://www.westcoastgreenhighway.com/pdfs/PEVregistrationbycountybymake.pdf |website=West Coast Green Highway |publisher=Washington State Department of Transportation |accessdate=22 April 2017}}</ref> The [[Seattle metropolitan area]] concentrated 76% of the state PEV registrations, with 18,154 plug-ins in [[King County, Washington|King County]] (59%), where the city of [[Seattle]] is located, 3,153 in [[Snohomish County, Washington|Snohomish County]] (10.3%), and 2,040 in [[Pierce County, Washington|Pierce County]] (6.6%). Outside the metro area, [[Clark County, Washington|Clark County]] has the largest number of PEV registrations with 1,467 units (4.8%).<ref name="WSDOT2016" />
[[File:E-Vehicles Added to City Fleet 3.jpg|thumb|The City of Seattle operates the [[Nissan Leaf]] as part of its fleet]]
Washington was the top selling all-electric car market in the U.S. at the state level in 2013 with a 1.40% [[market share]] of new light-vehicle registrations, ahead of California (1.28%). Washington PEV share in 2013 was more than four times the national average share of 0.32%.<ref name=TopBEVsates2013_062014/> In the 12 months between April 2013 and March 2014, [[Seattle metropolitan area|Seattle-Tacoma]] metro ranked as the third top selling all-electric car metropolitan market with a 1.83% market share of total new light-vehicle sales, only behind [[San Francisco Bay Area|San Francisco-Oakland-San Jose]] (3.33%) and [[Atlanta metropolitan area|Atlanta]] (2.15%).<ref name=TopBEVmetro/>
======Incentives======
New passenger cars, light-duty trucks, and medium-duty passenger vehicles that operate exclusively on electricity, hydrogen, natural gas, or propane are exempt from state motor vehicle sales and use taxes. Qualified vehicles must also meet the California motor vehicle emissions standards, and comply with the rules of the [[Washington Department of Ecology]].<ref name=WASincentives/> The initial sales tax exemption expired on July 1, 2015.<ref name=WASincentives>{{cite web |url=http://www.afdc.energy.gov/laws/8260 |title=Alternative Fuel Vehicle (AFV) Tax Exemption (Washington state) |author=[[Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy]] |publisher=Alternative Fuels Data Center |date=2014-06-04 |accessdate=2014-09-28}}</ref> The sales tax exemption was renewed on July 1, 2015, for four years, but the incentive was limited to new plug-in cars that cost less than {{USD|35,000}}. The approved cap excludes what legislators considered as luxury cars such as [[Tesla Motors]] and [[BMW i]] electric models. The same legislations that extended the incentives through 2019, raised the annual registration renewal fee for plug-in car owners from {{USD|100}} to {{USD|150}}. That annual fee is designed to make electric vehicle drivers contribute toward highway maintenance in lieu of the gas taxes PEVs do not pay.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.opb.org/news/article/npr-tesla-bmw-culled-from-washington-state-electric-car-sales-tax-break/ |title=Tesla, BMW Culled From Washington State Electric Car Sales Tax Break |first=Tom |last=Banse |work=[[Oregon Public Broadcasting|Oregon Public Broadcasting (OPB)]] |date=2015-07-01 |accessdate=2016-04-20}}</ref>
[[File:Tesla Model S in Fukushima 02 cropped.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Tesla Model S]] and other plug-in electric cars with purchase price above {{USD|42,500}} or [[plug-in hybrid]]s with an [[all-electric range]] of less than {{convert|30|mi|abbr=on}} are not eligible for the tax exemption in Washington state.]]
In April 2016 governor [[Jay Inslee]] signed legislation to provide up to about {{USD|3,100}} off the purchase or lease of a new car all-electric vehicle, or a plug-in hybrid with at least {{convert|30|mi|abbr=on}} of [[all-electric range]] – such as the [[Chevrolet Volt]] and the [[BMW i3 REx]]. The new law also raises the previous purchase price cap to {{USD|42,500}}, which will allow buyers of the [[Chevrolet Bolt EV]], the next generation Nissan Leaf, and the [[Tesla Model 3]] – all with {{convert|200|mi|abbr=on}} of electric range – to be eligible for the incentive. The new law goes into effect on July 1, 2016. Under the updatede scheme, the sales tax exemption applies to the first {{USD|32,000}} of the selling price of a qualifying new plug-in electric car, which translates into a tax savings between {{USD|2,600}} to {{USD|3,100}} for plug-in car buyers depending on where the dealer is located within the state, as the sales tax vary by county. The tax exemption could expire before July 2019 if sales of electric vehicles accelerate because legislators established that the tax break should end the month after 7,500 qualifying vehicles are sold in the state. The state Department of Licensing was directed to start a tally beginning with PEV registrations since July 15, 2015.<ref name=WAS122015>{{cite web |url=http://insideevs.com/washington-launches-3100-electric-vehicle-incentive-program/ |title=Washington Expands Electric Vehicle Incentive Program, Discounts Up To $3,100 |first=Jay |last=Cole |publisher=InsideEVs.com |date=2016-04-19 |accessdate=2016-04-19}} ''See notes in EV map by county''.</ref><ref name="Banse"/> {{As of|2016|04}}, the state sales tax is 6.5%, and increases up to 9.8% depending on the county rate.<ref name=WAS122015/>
[[Puget Sound Energy]] (PSE) provides a {{USD|500}} rebate to the first 5,000 qualified customers for the purchase and installation of [[Charging station#Standards|Level 2 electric vehicle charging station]] (EVSE). Eligible applicants must be PSE residential electric schedule 7 customers, must be the registered owner of an electric vehicle, and must install the charging station within a specified timeframe. PSE expects the rebate program to remain available until November 1, 2016, depending on available funds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pse.com/savingsandenergycenter/AlternativeFuelVehicles/Pages/Alternative-Fuel-Vehicles-for-Individuals.aspx |title=Electric vehicle charger rebate |author=[[Puget Sound Energy]] (PSE) |publisher=PSE |accessdate=2014-09-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.afdc.energy.gov/laws/11505 |title=Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment (EVSE) Rebate - PSE (Washington state) |author=[[Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy]] |publisher=Alternative Fuels Data Center |date=2014-06-04 |accessdate=2014-09-28}}</ref>
===Sales by model===
{{As of|2017|12}}, there were 41 highway legal plug-in cars available in the American market for retail sales, 16 all-electric cars and 25 plug-in hybrids.<ref name=ModelS200k>{{ cite news | url=http://www.hybridcars.com/tesla-quietly-sold-200000th-model-s-last-year/ |title=Tesla Quietly Sold 200,000th Model S Last Year | first= Jeff | last=Cobb | work= HybridCars.com | date=2018-01-22 |accessdate=2018-01-22}} "Tesla sold its 200,000 Model S in the fourth quarter of 2017, in October or early November, becoming the second plug-in car to cross this sales threshold after the Nissan Leaf (300,000 units by early 2017). {{As of|2017|12}}, Tesla reported global sales of 212,874 Model S cars." </ref> {{As of|2016|12}}, sales were concentrated to a few models, with only seven selling more than 1,000 units sold in December 2016, and the top 5 best selling plug-in cars accounting for about 65% of total 2016 sales.<ref name=PEVvsHEV2017/> Car manufacturers are offering plug-in electric cars in the U.S. for retail customers under 19 brands or marques: [[Audi]], [[BMW]], [[Cadillac]], [[Chevrolet]], [[Chrysler]], [[Fiat]], [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]], [[Honda]], [[Hyundai Motor Company|Hyundai]], [[Kia Motors|Kia]], [[Mercedes-Benz]], [[Mitsubishi Motors|Mitsubishi]], [[Nissan]], [[Porsche]], [[Smart (marque)|Smart]], [[Tesla, Inc.|Tesla]], [[Toyota]], [[Volkswagen]], and [[Volvo]].<ref name=PEVvsHEV2017/>
{{As of|2016|09}}, only the Chevrolet Volt, Nissan Leaf, Tesla's Model S and Model X, BMW i3, Mitsubishi i, Porsche Panamera S E-Hybrid, Cadillac ELR, and Ford’s C-Max and Fusion Energi plug-in hybrids were available nationwide. Several models, such as the Toyota RAV4, Fiat 500e, Honda Fit EV, and Chevrolet Spark EV, are compliance cars sold in limited markets, mainly California, available in order to raise an automaker’s fleet average fuel economy to satisfy regulator requirements.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/has-the-electrification-revolution-fizzled/ |title=Has The Electrification Revolution Fizzled? |author=Jeff Cobb |publisher=HybridCars.com |date=2014-08-13 |accessdate=2014-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/eight-perks-of-owning-an-electric-car/ |title=Eight Perks of Owning an Electric Car |author=Jeff Cobb |publisher=HybridCars.com |date=2014-11-14 |accessdate=2014-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://insideevs.com/porsche-panamera-s-e-hybrid-available-at-all-porsche-dealerships-nationwide/ |title=Porsche Panamera S E-Hybrid Available at All Porsche Dealerships Nationwide |author=Eric Loveday |publisher=InsideEVs.com |date=2013-12-20 |accessdate=2014-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.plugincars.com/cadillac-elr-selling-nationwide-only-about-half-dealerships-129432.html |title=Cadillac ELR Is Selling Nationwide, But At Only About Half of Dealerships |author=Alysha Webb |publisher=PluginCars.com |date=2014-02-26 |accessdate=2014-11-15}}</ref> {{As of|2016|04}}, out of the 14 plug-in hybrid models available in the American market, nine were upscale models affordable only for high income customers, namely the BMW X5 xDrive, Audi A3 e-tron, Porsche Cayenne and Panamera S E-Hybrids, Volvo XC90 T8, Mercedes S500, BMW i8, 3 Series iPerformance, and the Cadillac ELR, all priced above {{USD|40,000}}. Among all-electric cars, the BMW i3, Tesla Model S and Model X are also in the upscale category.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/18-hurdles-electrified-vehicles-are-having-to-overcome/ |title=18 Hurdles Electrified Vehicles Are Having To Overcome |first=Jeff |last=Cobb |work=HybridCars.com |date=2016-05-24 |accessdate=2016-05-24}}</ref>

==== Car dealers' reluctance to sell ====
With [[Tesla US dealership disputes|the exception]] of [[Tesla Motors]], almost all new cars in the United States are sold through dealerships, so they play a crucial role in the sales of electric vehicles, and negative attitudes can hinder early adoption of plug-in electric vehicles.<ref name=NYT11242015>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/01/science/electric-car-auto-dealers.html?hpw&rref=science&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&module=well-region&region=bottom-well&WT.nav=bottom-well |title=A Car Dealers Won't Sell: It's Electric |author=Matt Ritchel |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2015-11-24 |accessdate=2015-11-28}}</ref><ref name=UCDavis2014>{{cite web |url=http://www.its.ucdavis.edu/blog-post/the-future-of-electric-vehicles-part-1-car-dealers-hold-the-key/ |title=The Future Of Electric Vehicles Part 1: Car Dealers Hold The Key |author1=Eric Cahill |author2=Dan Sperling |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=[[Institute of Transportation Studies]] (ITS), at the [[University of California, Davis]] |date=2014-11-03 |accessdate=2015-11-28}}</ref> Dealers decide which cars they want to stock, and a salesperson can have a big impact on how someone feels about a prospective purchase. Sales people have ample knowledge of internal combustion cars while they do not have time to learn about a technology that represents a fraction of overall sales.<ref name=NYT11242015/> As with any new technology, and in the particular case of advanced technology vehicles, retailers are central to ensuring that buyers, especially those switching to a new technology, have the information and support they need to gain the full benefits of adopting this new technology.<ref name=UCDavis2014/> A 2016 study indicated that 60% of Americans were not aware of electric cars.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20161208005809/en/High-Costs-Lack-Awareness-Threaten-Short-Electric |title=High Costs, Lack of Awareness Threaten to Short Out Electric Vehicle Adoption - Business Wire |date=2016-12-08 |publisher= |accessdate=2017-01-02}}</ref>
[[File:DCA 06 2012 Chevy Volt 4034.JPG|thumb|Car dealerships play a crucial role in the sales of plug-in electric vehicles. Shown is a [[Chevrolet]] dealership exhibiting first-generation [[Chevrolet Volt|Volt]]s.]]
There are several reasons for the reluctance of some dealers to sell plug-in electric vehicles. PEVs do not offer car dealers the same profits as gasoline-powered car. Plug-in electric vehicles take more time to sell because of the explaining required, which hurts overall sales and sales people commissions. Electric vehicles also may require less maintenance, resulting in loss of service revenue, and thus undermining the biggest source of dealer profits, their service departments. According to the [[National Automobile Dealers Association]] (NADS), dealers on average make three times as much profit from service as they do from new car sales. However, a NADS spokesman said there was not sufficient data to prove that electric cars would require less maintenance.<ref name=NYT11242015/> According to [[the New York Times]], [[BMW]] and [[Nissan]] are among the companies whose dealers tend to be more enthusiastic and informed, but only about 10% of dealers are knowledgeable on the new technology.<ref name=NYT11242015/>
A study conducted at the [[Institute of Transportation Studies]] (ITS), at the [[University of California, Davis]] (UC Davis) published in 2014 found that many car dealers are less than enthusiastic about plug-in vehicles. ITS conducted 43 interviews with six automakers and 20 new car dealers selling plug-in vehicles in California’s major metro markets. The study also analyzed national and state-level [[J.D. Power]] 2013 Sales Satisfaction Index (SSI) study data on customer satisfaction with new car dealerships and [[Tesla US dealership disputes|Tesla retail stores]]. The researchers found that buyers of plug-in electric vehicles were significantly less satisfied and rated the dealer purchase experience much lower than buyers of non-premium conventional cars, while Tesla Motors earned industry-high scores. According to the findings, plug-in buyers expect more from dealers than conventional buyers, including product knowledge and support that extends beyond traditional offerings.<ref name=UCDavis2014/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.its.ucdavis.edu/research/publications/publication-detail/?pub_id=2353 |title=New Car Dealers and Retail Innovation in California’s Plug-In Electric Vehicle Market |first1=Eric |last1=Cahill |first2=Jamie |last2=Davies-Shawhyde |first3=Thomas S. |last3=Turrentine |publisher=[[Institute of Transportation Studies]] (ITS), at the [[University of California, Davis]] |date=October 2014 |accessdate=2015-11-29}} ''Working Paper – UCD-ITS-WP-14-04. Click on the bar "Download PDF"''</ref>
In 2014 ''[[Consumer Reports]]'' published results from a survey conducted with 19 secret shoppers that went to 85 dealerships in four states, making anonymous visits between December 2013 and March 2014. The secret shoppers asked a number of specific questions about cars to test the salespeople’s knowledge about electric cars. The consumer magazine decided to conduct the survey after several consumers who wanted to buy a plug-in car reported to the organization that some dealerships were steering them toward gasoline-powered models. The survey found that not all sales people seemed enthusiastic about making PEV sales; a few outright discouraged it, and even one dealer was reluctant to even show a plug-in model despite having one in stock. And many sales people seemed not to have a good understanding of electric-car tax breaks and other incentives or of charging needs and costs. ''Consumer Reports'' also found that when it came to answering basic questions, sales people at [[Chevrolet]], [[Ford]], and Nissan dealerships tended to be better informed than those at [[Honda]] and [[Toyota]]. The survey found that most of the Toyota dealerships visited recommended against buying a [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid|Prius Plug-in]] and suggested buying a standard [[Toyota Prius|Prius hybrid]] instead. Overall, the secret shoppers reported that only 13 dealers “discouraged sale of EV,” with seven of them being in New York. However, at 35 of the 85 dealerships visited, the secret shoppers said sales people recommended buying a gasoline-powered car instead.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/news/2014/04/dealers-not-always-plugged-in-about-electric-cars-secret-shopper-study-reveals/index.htm |title=Dealers not always plugged in about electric cars, Consumer Reports’ study reveals |author=Eric Evarts |work=[[Consumer Reports]] |date=2014-04-22 |accessdate=2015-11-29}}</ref>
The ITS-Davis study also found that a small but influential minority of dealers have introduced new approaches to better meet the needs of plug-in customers. Examples include marketing [[High-occupancy vehicle lane|carpool lane]] stickers, enrolling buyers in charging networks, and preparing incentive paperwork for customers. Some dealers assign seasoned sales people as plug-in experts, many of whom drive plug-ins themselves to learn and be familiar with the technology and relate the cars' benefits to potential buyers. The study concluded also that carmakers could do much more to support dealers selling PEVs.<ref name=UCDavis2014/>
====Future trends==== [[File:Barack Obama driving at the White House.jpg|thumb|[[President Obama]] driving a Volt at the [[White House]]]]
According to a 2011 study by Pike Research, annual sales of plug-in electric vehicles in the U.S. were predicted to reach 360,000 vehicles by 2017. The study projected that the highest sales between 2011 and 2017 would take place in California, New York and Florida.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pikeresearch.com/newsroom/electric-vehicle-penetration-rates-to-be-highest-in-smaller-states |title=Electric Vehicle Penetration Rates to be Highest in Smaller States |author=Pike Research |publisher=Pike Research |date=2011-09-23 |accessdate=2012-06-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606075857/http://www.pikeresearch.com/newsroom/electric-vehicle-penetration-rates-to-be-highest-in-smaller-states |archivedate=2012-06-06 |df= }}</ref> In 2012, and as sales have fallen short of projections, Pike Research projected that annual sales of plug-in electric vehicles in the U.S. will reach 400,073 units in 2020, with California as the state with the highest PEV sales over the remainder of this decade, with nearly 25% of all PEVs sold in the United States between 2012 and 2020. In terms of market share, California will be followed by New York, Florida, Texas, and Washington, but Hawaii is expected by 2020 to have the highest penetration rate of PEVs as a percentage of all light duty vehicle sales. California is predicted to have four of the top ten metropolitan areas for PEV sales: [[Los Angeles metropolitan area|Los Angeles–Long Beach]], [[San Francisco Bay Area]], [[Silicon Valley]], and [[Sacramento metropolitan area|Greater Sacramento]]. Pike Research forecasts that cumulative sales of PEVs in the largest 102 American cities will reach more than 1.8 million from 2012 through 2020, with a share of more than 25% of all annual sales concentrated in the top five metropolitan areas for PEV sales: New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, and Portland.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pikeresearch.com/research/electric-vehicle-geographic-forecasts |title=Electric Vehicle Geographic Forecasts |author=Pike Research |publisher=Pike Research |date=2013-03-01 |accessdate=2013-03-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130126062103/http://www.pikeresearch.com/research/electric-vehicle-geographic-forecasts |archivedate=2013-01-26 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pikeresearch.com/newsroom/nearly-1-in-4-plug-in-electric-vehicles-sold-in-the-united-states-from-2012-to-2020-will-be-sold-in-california |title=Nearly 1 in 4 Plug-In Electric Vehicles Sold in the United States From 2012 to 2020 Will be Sold in California |author=Pike Research |publisher=Pike Research |date=2012-09-18 |accessdate=2013-03-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022063648/http://www.pikeresearch.com/newsroom/nearly-1-in-4-plug-in-electric-vehicles-sold-in-the-united-states-from-2012-to-2020-will-be-sold-in-california |archivedate=2012-10-22 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pikeresearch.com/newsroom/more-than-1-8-million-plug-in-electric-vehicles-will-be-sold-in-the-largest-102-u-s-cities-from-2012-to-2020 |title=More than 1.8 Million Plug-In Electric Vehicles Will Be Sold in the Largest 102 U.S. Cities From 2012 to 2020 |author=Pike Research |publisher=Pike Research |date=2013-01-21 |accessdate=2013-03-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130124235316/http://www.pikeresearch.com/newsroom/more-than-1-8-million-plug-in-electric-vehicles-will-be-sold-in-the-largest-102-u-s-cities-from-2012-to-2020 |archivedate=2013-01-24 |df= }}</ref>
In a separate analysis published in September 2013, [[Navigant Consulting|Navigant Research]] forecasts that PEVs will represent a 2.4% [[market share]] of total new vehicle sales in the United States in 2022. Navigant also predicted that Hawaii will have the highest concentration of plug-in electric vehicle sales in the U.S., with 10.1% of total Hawaiian new [[light-duty vehicle]] sales in 2022; followed by [[Northern California]] with 9.7%, California as a whole will be 6.0%, and Oregon with 5.8%.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2013/09/20130910-navigant.html |title=Navigant forecasts 18.6% CAGR for plug-ins in North America to 2022; 2.4% new vehicle share in US |author=Navigant Research |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2013-09-10 |accessdate=2013-09-30}}</ref> Hawaii has a high potential for mass adoption of plug-in electric vehicles due to the limited driving range imposed by the islands size and its high fuel costs.<ref name=HawaiiParadise>{{cite web |url=http://www.plugincars.com/hawaii-becoming-ev-paradise-128418.html |title=Hawaii Becoming an EV Paradise |author=John Gartner |publisher=PluginCars.com |date=2013-09-26 |accessdate=2013-09-30}}</ref><ref name=EVHawaii>{{cite web |url=http://www.mauieva.org/docs/EVparadise.pdf |title=Electric Vehicle Paradise: How Hawai'i Can Lead the World in Deployment |author=Berkeley Law, [[University of California, Berkeley]] and [[University of Hawaii Maui College|Maui College]], [[University of Hawaiʻi]] |publisher=Maui Vehicle Alliance (Maui EVA) |date=September 2013 |accessdate=2013-09-30}}</ref> In an updated report published in April 2014 Navigant forecasts that the United States will remain the largest national market for light-duty plug-in electric vehicles during the next 10 years, with the PEV segment growing at a compound annual growth rate of 16.3% between 2014 and 2023, predicting that annual PEV sales in the U.S. will exceed 514,000 in 2023.<ref name=Navigant2014>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2014/04/20140424-navigant.html |title=Navigant: US to remain largest national plug-in vehicle market over next 10 years; Tokyo to take metro market lead spot from LA |author=[[Navigant Consulting|Navigant Research]] |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2014-04-24 |accessdate=2014-04-27}}</ref>
According to forecasts made by Pike Research in January 2013, the United States was expected to continue to be the largest market for PEVs in 2020, but the European market was anticipated to have a higher market penetration (4.0% market share) due to its higher gasoline prices and supportive government policies, while Japan was expected to become the largest market for hybrid electric vehicles.<ref name=Pike2013>{{cite web |url=http://www.pikeresearch.com/newsroom/worldwide-electric-vehicle-sales-to-reach-3-8-million-annually-by-2020 |title=Worldwide Electric Vehicle Sales to Reach 3.8 Million Annually by 2020 |author=Pike Research |publisher=Pike Research |date=2013-01-03 |accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2013/01/pikeeuev-20130102.html |title=Pike Research forecasts hybrids and plug-ins to grow to 4% of European market in 2020 |author=Pike Research |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2013-01-02 |accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref> A similar trend was predicted by Navigant Research in a geographical forecast published in April 2014. Navigant predicted that by 2023 the fleet of light duty plug-in electric vehicles in use in [[Greater Oslo Region|Oslo]] is expected to represent 10.7% of the city's total registered light-duty fleet, 7.7% in [[Amsterdam Metropolitan Area|Amsterdam]], and 2.5% in [[Paris Metropolitan Area|Paris]]. Navigant also predicts that by 2020 annual PEV sales in the [[Greater Tokyo Area]] will surpass Los Angeles, currently the city with the largest PEV market. The PEV fleet in Tokyo is expected to reach a market penetration of 2.3% of the city's light-duty stock in 2023, and become the world's largest PEV city market with a PEV stock of around 260,000 in 2023, while Los Angeles is expected to have a stock of over 250,000 PEVs.<ref name=Navigant2014_2>{{cite web |url=http://www.navigantresearch.com/wp-assets/uploads/2014/04/EVGEO-14-Executive-Summary.pdf |title=Executive Summary: Electric Vehicle Geographic Forecasts - Plug-In Electric Vehicle Sales Forecasts for North America and Select European and Asia Pacific Cities by State/Province, Metropolitan Area, City, and Selected Utility Service Territories |publisher=[[Navigant Consulting|Navigant Research]] |author1=Scott Shepard |author2=John Gartner |lastauthoramp=yes |date=April 2014 |accessdate=2014-04-27}} ''See Chart 1.1 for annual LD PEV sales in Los Angeles, Tokyo and Paris between 2014 and 2023.''</ref>
